django.test.client.encode_multipart(boundary, data)[source]

Encode multipart POST data from a dictionary of form values.

The key will be used as the form data name; the value will be transmitted as content. If the value is a file, the contents of the file will be sent as an application/octet-stream; otherwise, str(value) will be sent.

django.test.client.encode_file(boundary, key, file)[source]
class django.test.client.RequestFactory(*, json_encoder=DjangoJSONEncoder, headers=None, **defaults)[source]

Class that lets you create mock Request objects for use in testing.

Usage:

rf = RequestFactory() get_request = rf.get(‘/hello/’) post_request = rf.post(‘/submit/’, {‘foo’: ‘bar’})

Once you have a request object you can pass it to any view function, just as if that view had been hooked up using a URLconf.

class django.test.client.AsyncRequestFactory(*, json_encoder=DjangoJSONEncoder, headers=None, **defaults)[source]

Bases: RequestFactory

Class that lets you create mock ASGI-like Request objects for use in testing. Usage:

rf = AsyncRequestFactory() get_request = await rf.get(‘/hello/’) post_request = await rf.post(‘/submit/’, {‘foo’: ‘bar’})

Once you have a request object you can pass it to any view function, including synchronous ones. The reason we have a separate class here is: a) this makes ASGIRequest subclasses, and b) AsyncTestClient can subclass it.

request(**request)[source]

Construct a generic request object.

generic(method, path, data='', content_type='application/octet-stream', secure=False, *, headers=None, **extra)[source]

Construct an arbitrary HTTP request.

class django.test.client.Client(enforce_csrf_checks=False, raise_request_exception=True, *, headers=None, **defaults)[source]

Bases: ClientMixin, RequestFactory

A class that can act as a client for testing purposes.

It allows the user to compose GET and POST requests, and obtain the response that the server gave to those requests. The server Response objects are annotated with the details of the contexts and templates that were rendered during the process of serving the request.

Client objects are stateful - they will retain cookie (and thus session) details for the lifetime of the Client instance.

This is not intended as a replacement for Twill/Selenium or the like - it is here to allow testing against the contexts and templates produced by a view, rather than the HTML rendered to the end-user.

handler[source]

headers = None[source]
request(**request)[source]

Make a generic request. Compose the environment dictionary and pass to the handler, return the result of the handler. Assume defaults for the query environment, which can be overridden using the arguments to the request.

class django.test.client.AsyncClient(enforce_csrf_checks=False, raise_request_exception=True, *, headers=None, **defaults)[source]

Bases: ClientMixin, AsyncRequestFactory

An async version of Client that creates ASGIRequests and calls through an async request path.

Does not currently support “follow” on its methods.
